# Mario Charts - Complete Documentation for LLMs

> A modern React component library focused on charts and dashboards with beautiful visuals out-of-the-box.

## Overview

Mario Charts provides production-ready, copy-paste chart components for React applications. Built with TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, and Framer Motion for animations.

## Installation

### CLI Installation (Recommended)
```bash
# Initialize project
npx mario-charts@latest init

# Add components
npx mario-charts@latest add bar-chart
npx mario-charts@latest add line-chart
npx mario-charts@latest add pie-chart
```

### Manual Dependencies
```bash
npm install recharts framer-motion @radix-ui/react-tooltip class-variance-authority clsx tailwind-merge
```

---

## Components Reference

### 1. BarChart

**Description:** Vertical and horizontal bar charts for comparing categorical data.

**Import:**
```tsx
import { BarChart } from "@/components/charts/bar-chart";
```

**Props:**
| Prop | Type | Default | Description |
|------|------|---------|-------------|
| data | T[] | required | Array of data objects |
| x | keyof T | required | Key for x-axis labels |
| y | keyof T | "value" | Key for y-axis values |
| colors | string[] | DEFAULT_COLORS | Bar colors |
| variant | "filled" \| "outline" | "filled" | Visual style |
| orientation | "vertical" \| "horizontal" | "vertical" | Bar direction |
| height | number | 300 | Chart height in pixels |
| animation | boolean | true | Enable animations |
| loading | boolean | false | Show loading state |
| error | string \| null | null | Error message |
| onBarClick | (data: T, index: number) => void | - | Click handler |
| className | string | - | Additional CSS classes |

**Example:**
```tsx
const data = [
  { month: "Jan", revenue: 4500 },
  { month: "Feb", revenue: 5200 },
  { month: "Mar", revenue: 4800 },
];

<BarChart
  data={data}
  x="month"
  y="revenue"
  colors={["#3b82f6"]}
  variant="filled"
  orientation="vertical"
/>
```

---

### 2. LineChart

**Description:** Line charts for time series and continuous data visualization with multiple series support.

**Import:**
```tsx
import { LineChart } from "@/components/charts/line-chart";
```

**Props:**
| Prop | Type | Default | Description |
|------|------|---------|-------------|
| data | T[] | required | Array of data objects |
| x | keyof T | required | Key for x-axis labels |
| y | keyof T \| (keyof T)[] | required | Key(s) for y-axis values |
| colors | string[] | DEFAULT_COLORS | Line colors |
| curve | "linear" \| "monotone" \| "natural" \| "step" | "monotone" | Curve interpolation |
| showDots | boolean | true | Show data points |
| showArea | boolean | false | Fill area under line |
| connectNulls | boolean | true | Connect across null values |
| strokeWidth | number | 2 | Line width |
| height | number | 300 | Chart height |
| animation | boolean | true | Enable animations |
| onPointClick | (data: T, index: number, series?: string) => void | - | Click handler |

**Example:**
```tsx
const data = [
  { month: "Jan", revenue: 4500, users: 1200 },
  { month: "Feb", revenue: 5200, users: 1400 },
];

// Single line
<LineChart data={data} x="month" y="revenue" />

// Multiple lines
<LineChart
  data={data}
  x="month"
  y={["revenue", "users"]}
  colors={["#3b82f6", "#10b981"]}
  curve="monotone"
  showArea={true}
/>
```

---

### 3. PieChart

**Description:** Pie, donut, and semi-circle charts for visualizing proportions and distributions.

**Import:**
```tsx
import { PieChart } from "@/components/charts/pie-chart";
```

**Props:**
| Prop | Type | Default | Description |
|------|------|---------|-------------|
| data | T[] | required | Array of data objects |
| value | keyof T | required | Key for slice values |
| label | keyof T | required | Key for slice labels |
| variant | "pie" \| "donut" \| "semi" | "donut" | Chart style |
| innerRadius | number | 0.6 | Inner radius (0-1) for donut |
| centerContent | ReactNode \| ((data) => ReactNode) | - | Center content |
| colors | string[] | DEFAULT_COLORS | Slice colors |
| height | number | 300 | Chart height |
| animation | boolean | true | Enable animations |
| onSliceClick | (data: T, index: number) => void | - | Click handler |

**Example:**
```tsx
const data = [
  { category: "Engineering", amount: 450000 },
  { category: "Marketing", amount: 280000 },
  { category: "Sales", amount: 320000 },
];

<PieChart
  data={data}
  value="amount"
  label="category"
  variant="donut"
  centerContent={({ total }) => (
    <div className="text-center">
      <div className="text-2xl font-bold">${(total / 1000).toFixed(0)}K</div>
      <div className="text-xs text-muted-foreground">Total</div>
    </div>
  )}
/>
```

---

### 4. RadarChart

**Description:** Radar/spider charts for comparing multiple quantitative variables across categories.

**Import:**
```tsx
import { RadarChart } from "@/components/charts/radar-chart";
```

**Props:**
| Prop | Type | Default | Description |
|------|------|---------|-------------|
| series | RadarSeries[] | required | Array of data series |
| axes | RadarAxis[] | required | Axis configurations |
| colors | string[] | DEFAULT_COLORS | Series colors |
| height | number | 400 | Chart height |
| showAxisLabels | boolean | true | Show axis labels |
| showDots | boolean | true | Show data point dots |
| fillOpacity | number | 0.25 | Polygon fill opacity |
| strokeWidth | number | 2 | Line stroke width |
| animation | boolean | true | Enable animations |
| onSeriesClick | (series, index) => void | - | Click handler |

**Types:**
```tsx
interface RadarSeries<T> {
  id: string;
  name: string;
  data: T;
  color?: string;
}

interface RadarAxis {
  key: string;
  label: string;
  min?: number;
  max?: number;
}
```

**Example:**
```tsx
const series = [
  {
    id: "player1",
    name: "Player 1",
    data: { pace: 85, shooting: 92, passing: 91, dribbling: 95 },
  },
];

const axes = [
  { key: "pace", label: "PAC" },
  { key: "shooting", label: "SHO" },
  { key: "passing", label: "PAS" },
  { key: "dribbling", label: "DRI" },
];

<RadarChart series={series} axes={axes} fillOpacity={0.3} />
```

---

### 5. ScatterPlot

**Description:** Scatter plots and bubble charts for visualizing relationships between variables.

**Import:**
```tsx
import { ScatterPlot } from "@/components/charts/scatter-plot";
```

**Props:**
| Prop | Type | Default | Description |
|------|------|---------|-------------|
| data | T[] | required | Array of data objects |
| x | keyof T | required | Key for x-axis values |
| y | keyof T | required | Key for y-axis values |
| series | keyof T | - | Key to group by series |
| size | keyof T \| number | 6 | Point size or data key |
| sizeRange | [number, number] | [4, 40] | Min/max bubble size |
| colors | string[] | DEFAULT_COLORS | Point colors |
| showTrendLine | boolean | false | Show regression line |
| showLegend | boolean | false | Show legend |
| showGrid | boolean | false | Show grid lines |
| xDomain | [number, number] | - | Custom x-axis domain |
| yDomain | [number, number] | - | Custom y-axis domain |
| height | number | 300 | Chart height |
| animation | boolean | true | Enable animations |
| onPointClick | (data: T, index: number, series?: string) => void | - | Click handler |

**Example:**
```tsx
// Basic scatter plot
const data = [
  { experience: 1, salary: 45000 },
  { experience: 3, salary: 55000 },
  { experience: 5, salary: 70000 },
];

<ScatterPlot
  data={data}
  x="experience"
  y="salary"
  showTrendLine={true}
  showGrid={true}
/>

// Bubble chart
const countries = [
  { gdp: 63000, lifeExpectancy: 78.9, population: 331000000 },
];

<ScatterPlot
  data={countries}
  x="gdp"
  y="lifeExpectancy"
  size="population"
  sizeRange={[10, 60]}
/>
```

---

### 6. StackedBarChart

**Description:** Stacked bar charts for comparing composition across different groups.

**Import:**
```tsx
import { StackedBarChart } from "@/components/charts/stacked-bar-chart";
```

**Props:**
| Prop | Type | Default | Description |
|------|------|---------|-------------|
| data | T[] | required | Array of data objects |
| x | keyof T | required | Key for x-axis labels |
| y | (keyof T)[] | required | Keys to stack |
| colors | string[] | DEFAULT_COLORS | Segment colors |
| variant | "filled" \| "outline" | "filled" | Visual style |
| orientation | "vertical" \| "horizontal" | "vertical" | Stacking direction |
| showLegend | boolean | false | Show legend |
| height | number | 300 | Chart height |
| animation | boolean | true | Enable animations |
| onSegmentClick | (data: T, stackKey: string, index: number) => void | - | Click handler |

**Example:**
```tsx
const data = [
  { month: "Jan", desktop: 4200, mobile: 2400, services: 1800 },
  { month: "Feb", desktop: 5100, mobile: 2800, services: 2200 },
];

<StackedBarChart
  data={data}
  x="month"
  y={["desktop", "mobile", "services"]}
  colors={["#3b82f6", "#10b981", "#f59e0b"]}
  showLegend={true}
  variant="filled"
  orientation="vertical"
/>
```

---

## Default Color Palette

```typescript
const DEFAULT_COLORS = [
  "#3b82f6", // blue
  "#10b981", // green
  "#f59e0b", // amber
  "#ef4444", // red
  "#8b5cf6", // violet
  "#06b6d4", // cyan
];
```

---

## Common Patterns

### Loading State
All charts support a `loading` prop that displays a skeleton animation:
```tsx
<BarChart data={data} x="month" y="revenue" loading={true} />
```

### Error State
Display error messages with the `error` prop:
```tsx
<BarChart data={data} x="month" y="revenue" error="Failed to load data" />
```

### Empty State
Charts automatically handle empty data arrays with a friendly message.

### Responsive Behavior
All charts use ResizeObserver to adapt to container size changes automatically.

---
